continuous experimentation is an analytics problem at its core and a comparative analytics

i have observed that most of the discussion in the community around this topic tends

the idea is to assess the behavior of that version against success criteria that the user

the performance test it needs to have a mean latency below 120 milliseconds and an error rate
uh of at most 0.001 which means like four nines if

is meeting um performance uh criteria or error criteria
in this particular case relative criteria might be important for instance i might

gets applied so that the traffic hopefully will gradually shift to the canary if things
are going well and if the canary fails of course uh a rollback decision is made
yet another experiment type is a b or abn abn testing in this case there are
two or more versions being compared there's a baseline version and one or more candidates
and the idea here here typically is to maximize some type of reward metric that is
usually associated with the business and at the same time do so in a way that
service level objectives that you want to promise to your users are still being satisfied right
